text: some apples are best for desserts while
others are great in salads and some are
meant to be just eat right out of hand
but with so many varieties out there in
the marketplace almost 100 different
commercially grown apples it's hard to
figure out which ones are best suited
for what but I've taken the guesswork
out of all of it and I've organized
apples into two major categories so
within the firm category there's two
different distinctions tart apples and
sweet apples a tart apple that we all
know is the Granny Smith apple here and
Granny Smith Rome and northern spy are
those tart firm apples and they're
really great to bake with now to
compliment their tart flavor it's good
to introduce some of the sweeter firm
apples whenever you're baking so if
you're making an apple pie a mixture of
apples is always great and within this
sweet category we have Braeburn apples
Honey Crisp ginger gold Golden Delicious
Red Delicious Jonagold and Mutsu which
is also known as a Crispin Apple so
these apples are great in many different
baked goods from pies to baked apples to
tarts things like that they really do
hold their texture up to heat so they
don't kind of melt away into nothing now
tender apples are really great on salads
to make apple sauce you can make cider
out of them
or you can eat them right out of hand
actually and within this category again
there are two different classifications
tart and sweet so within the tart
category you have the Empire the
Macintosh and a Cortland
and the sweet category you have gala and
Fuji now for a simple test that will
show you how your apples will behave if
you take an assortment of apples I have
Granny Smith here I've Honey Crisp
McIntosh and a Fuji apple so I'm going
to cover this with two damp paper towels
and what the paper towels do is they
they keep the moisture in so that the
apples don't dry out you they actually
kind of soften overall and this goes
into the microwave for about two to
three minutes and we'll see how they'll
end up if they were baked
so it's been about three minutes you can
see how the apples have cooked up here
now this is the Granny Smith apple and I
can actually pick it up the Apple itself
because of its structure has maintained
its shape now this is the Honey Crisp
apple and it is also maintaining its
shape so that's these are two apples
from the firm category now from the
tender category we have the McIntosh
Apple and you can see it's starting to
fall apart it's very very soft and you
can actually see it's falling apart here
and that's actually really great if you
were using it for applesauce or
something like that because it is so
tender but if you were using it so low
in an apple pie you'd end up with kind
of mush in the bottom of your pie shell
we have the gala apple and you can see
that it hasn't really held its shape
very well either in the baking process
and it's kind of mushy so there you go
tender apples good for applesauce good
for salads maybe eating out of hand and
firm apples are really what's great for
baking don't be afraid to experiment
with new varieties of apples that you
may have never tried before try this
simple test and you'll know whether
they're good for baking whether they're
good for salads or whether they're just
good to eat right out of hand follow
these simple guidelines in choosing the
best Apple for the job will no longer be
a kitchen conundrum
you
